title: My Skin Hates Everything. This Pineapple Tallow Balm? It Doesn't.
body:
So my skin is a disaster. I’m talking dry, flaky patches that show up by like 2pm, but also weird oily bits on my forehead, and it all just gets angry and red if you look at it wrong. It’s winter, the heat’s on, and my face feels like old paper. I’ve tried the expensive stuff in the fancy jars, the drugstore stuff, the “clean beauty” goop that costs a fortune and smells like a forest floor. Nothing. It either sat on top like plastic wrap or made me break out in little bumps. I was desperate. Then I saw someone talking about a tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I thought, okay, that’s it, the internet has finally lost its mind.

But my hands were so cracked they hurt, and I was out of options. So I ordered this Whipped Tallow Balm in Pineapple from some little shop on Etsy. Figured if nothing else, the smell would be fun. A tropical escape in a jar while my skin fell off. Whatever.

Here’s the thing. It showed up on a Tuesday. I was in my gross sweatpants, the ones with the hole near the pocket. The box was smaller than I thought. I opened it right there in my kitchen, under the weird yellow light that makes everything look sick.

### How Beef Tallow for Skin Became My Last Resort

I need to back up. My skin type is… confused. My dermatologist, like five years ago, called it “combination with sensitivity.” I call it a pain. In winter, the dry parts get desert-level. The corners of my nose crack. My cheeks get tight, like I’m wearing a mask that’s two sizes too small. But I can’t slather on heavy creams because then my T-zone gets clogged and I get these under-the-skin bumps that never come to a head, they just sit there, being rude.

I spent so much money. There was that cult French cream everyone raves about. Felt like silk going on, did absolutely nothing. There was the gel moisturizer that was supposed to be “lightweight.” My skin drank it and asked for more in ten minutes. I was cycling through products, my bathroom shelf looked like a pharmacy, and my skin was just getting worse. More reactive. More unhappy.

So when I read about tallow balm, specifically a whipped tallow balm, I was at the “why not” stage. The logic made a weird kind of sense. Grass-fed beef tallow, the stuff rendered from suet, is supposed to be really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So instead of putting some alien, lab-made oil on your face, you’re using something your skin might actually recognize. It’s a natural moisturizer in the most literal, kinda gross-sounding way. Made in France, which I guess is where they know their fats? I don’t know. I was skeptical. Putting animal fat on my face felt very medieval. But my modern options had failed. So.

### What This Pineapple Tallow Balm Actually Does

The jar is cute. Simple. I unscrewed the lid. It smells… like pineapple. Not a fake, candy pineapple. Not like a cleaner. Like if you had a really ripe pineapple sitting on your counter in summer. Sweet, but not sickly. It smells cheerful. It just does. It made me smile, which was a good start because I was fully prepared to be grossed out.

The texture threw me. It’s whipped, so it’s this really light, almost fluffy cream. Not greasy like I pictured lard. I scooped a tiny bit with my finger. It felt cool. Solid, but as soon as you rub it between your fingers, it melts. It becomes this silky oil. I held my breath and patted it onto my dry, angry cheek.

Weird.
It didn’t sit there. It just… went in. Like my skin was thirsty and it was water. But it wasn’t water, it was this rich balm. There was no film. No shine, after a minute. Just skin that felt… calm. Not greasy. Not tight. Just normal. I kept poking my cheek. It felt soft, but like my own skin’s soft, not like I had something on it.

That first night, I used it as my last step. After my serum, which is another story of trial and error. I just patted a little more all over. Went to bed expecting to wake up a greaseball or with a new rash.

I didn’t.
I woke up and my face wasn’t tight. That morning dryness, that feeling like you need to splash water on it immediately? Gone. My skin just looked… rested. Not miraculously perfect, but quiet. The red patch on my left cheekbone was less angry. I was shocked. I used it again that morning. Just a tiny dab. It worked under my makeup, didn’t make me slick by noon. It just kept my skin from freaking out.

After a few days, I got brave. I used it on my cracked knuckles. On my elbows, which are always rough. Same thing. It healed the cracks on my hands faster than any “intensive repair” hand cream ever did. This tallow balm for dry, sensitive skin was doing the job. I started using it on my lips before bed. Best lip balm I’ve ever used, and I’ve used them all.

### My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

It’s been about a month now. I’m on my second jar. I never finish skincare products. I always get bored or they stop working. This one, I ran out and immediately re-ordered. That’s the biggest review I can give.

The changes are subtle but real. My skin doesn’t have those flaky patches anymore. At all. The overall texture is smoother. When I get out of the shower, I don’t have that five-minute panic to moisturize before my face seizes up. I can take my time. The sensitivity is way down. Wind doesn’t make it burn as much. That weird winter redness across my cheeks and nose has faded a ton. It’s not a miracle for fine lines or anything, but my skin just looks healthier. More resilient. Like it’s finally got what it needs.

It’s not perfect. If I use too much, it can feel a bit much on my forehead. So I use a pea-sized amount for my whole face. A little truly goes a long way. And the scent, while I love the pineapple tropical escape vibe, is pretty strong in the jar. It fades once it’s on your skin, but if you’re super sensitive to fragrance, maybe try an unscented one first. For me, the smell is part of the experience. It’s a little vacation in my boring winter routine.

I told my mom about it. She has even drier skin than me. She was horrified at first (“You put what on your face?”) but she tried it on her hands and now she’s asking me for the link. I got mine from **this little Etsy shop that makes it** – they just seem to know what they’re doing with the whipping process. It makes it so much nicer to use than just a hard balm.

### Would I Buy This Pineapple Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did.
Look, I’m not a skincare guru. I’m just someone whose skin was miserable and is now… not. This tallow balm for combination skin, for dry skin, for just pissed-off skin, it worked for me. It’s the best tallow I’ve tried for that deep dryness without the clogging. It feels simple and honest. No fifty ingredients I can’t pronounce. Just grass-fed tallow, some oils, and in my case, a smell that makes me happy.

It’s not magic. It won’t change your life. But if your skin is feeling rough, tight, and sensitive from the cold, and nothing else is cutting it, this might be worth a shot. It’s a natural moisturizer that actually moisturizes. Deeply. Without the fuss.

I keep it on my nightstand now. The little pineapple-scented jar. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.

Anyway, if you’re curious, might be worth checking out. My elbows haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid. No joke.

### Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. Because it’s so similar to the oils our skin already makes, it absorbs really well. It doesn’t just sit on top like a barrier—it sinks in and helps your skin barrier repair itself. It’s been used for ages for a reason.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me, and I’m prone to clogging. Because it mimics sebum, my theory is my skin doesn’t freak out and overproduce oil to compensate for dry patches, so everything just chills out. It’s non-comedogenic for most people. Start with a little.

**What does the Pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
Like a real, ripe pineapple. Sweet and fruity, not artificial. It’s strong in the jar but fades to almost nothing once it’s on your skin. It just gives you a cheerful little moment when you put it on. A summer vibe in the dead of winter.
